good.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: of a high standard or quality
good.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The train service is not very good.
My French is better than my Spanish.
You’ll receive the best medical treatment.
good.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Do you know a good builder?
Mike’s done a good job of painting the windows.
do/make a good job (of doing something)
Alex is very good at languages.
As a politician, you need to be good with words (=skilful at using words).
He’s very good with people (=skilful at dealing with people).
good.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: used about something that is what you want or happens in the way that you want
good.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: I need a bit of good luck.
good.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Did you have a good vacation?
It’s good to see you again.
good.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: likely to be successful or correct
good.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Well, can you think of a better plan?
What’s the best way to deal with this?
The police have a pretty good idea who did it.
I’m not sure, but I could make a good guess.
good.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Is this a good time to talk to you?
It was a good place to rest.
Ten o'clock is good for me.
It’s a good day for going to the beach.
good.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Do you want some good advice?
The best thing you can do is wait here.
You should make good use of your time.
good.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: behaving well and not causing any trouble – used especially about a child
good.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: The kids were as good as gold (=very good).
good.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: likely to make you healthy, either physically or mentally
good.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: They have to learn which wild foods are good to eat.
Fresh fruit and vegetables are good for you.
Watching too much TV isn’t good for you.
good.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: likely to improve the condition of something
good.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: products that are good for the environment
The publicity has been good for business.
good.translation[0].definitions[10].type: used especially in negatives and comparatives
good.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Lyn’s not feeling too good today.
good.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: if the condition of something is good, it is not damaged or weak
good.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: Once the boat’s repaired, it’ll be as good as new (=in perfect condition).
It’s in pretty good condition for an old car.
Boris had always kept his body in good shape.
The Chancellor announced that the economy is in good shape.
He sat up, supporting himself on his good arm.
good.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: kind and understanding about what other people need or want
good.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: The company’s always been very good to me.
Dad lent me the money. He was very good about it.
It was good of him to offer you a lift.
good.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: behaving correctly or being right according to accepted moral standards
good.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: I try to be good, but it isn’t always easy.
Well, that’s my good deed for the day (=something good you try to do for someone else every day).
I’m on the side of the good guys (=people who behave in a morally right way, for example in a film).
good.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: large in amount, size, range etc
good.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: We’ve had a good crop of apples.
There’s a good range of leisure facilities.
I’d been waiting a good while (=a fairly long time).
Our team has a good chance of winning  (=is fairly likely to win).
good.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: a good price is reasonable and not expensive
good.translation[0].definitions[15].exam: Thirty dollars sounds like a good price to me.
good.translation[0].definitions[16].defi: doing something for a long time, so that you do it completely and thoroughly
good.translation[0].definitions[16].exam: Take a good look at it.
She sat down and had a good cry.
This time he waited until he was good and ready (=completely ready).
good.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: of a high standard or quality
I’ve just read a really good book.
My French is not very good.
pleasant and enjoyable. Nice  is very common in spoken English. In written English, it is better to use other words
I hope you have a nice vacation.
It will be nice to see you again.
If you buy good quality shoes, they last much longer.
used for describing things of a very high quality, or weather with no rain and clear skies
The restaurant serves the finest food in Florence.
If it’s fine tomorrow, we’ll go for a walk.
good – used when you like something
They sell some really neat stuff.
an attractive offer, course of action etc seems good and makes you want to accept it or do it
Going home for dinner was a more attractive proposition than completing his run.
Buying direct from the manufacturer seems the most attractive option.
something that is impressive is good in a way that makes people admire it
It was a very impressive performance.
extremely good, in a surprising and exciting way
New York is an amazing place.
The skating has been incredible in this competition.
used about weather that is very pleasant and sunny
much better than other places, people etc
Occasionally, we get a student with exceptional talent.
Their chocolate cake is just out of this world!
good.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: USAGE: Good, well
good.translation[0].note_box[1].items[0]: Good is an adjective in standard English Well is an adverb
good.translation[0].note_box[1].items[1]: You will sometimes hear people say 'The team played good', especially in American English, but this is a non-standard use
good.translation[0].note_box[1].items[2]: The comparative form of both good and well is better
good.translation[0].note_box[1].items[3]: The superlative form of both good and well is best
good.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: used to say that you are pleased about something
good.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: ‘I got an A in biology, Mum.’ ‘Oh, good.’
good.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: used to tell someone that you think their work or what they are doing is good
good.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: behaviour, attitudes, forces etc that are morally right
good.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: She is definitely an influence for good on those boys.
There’s a lot of good in him, in spite of his rudeness.
the struggle between good and evil
good.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: well. Many teachers think this is not correct English
good.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The business is doing good now.
good.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: something that has been produced in order to be used or sold. The word is used in the singular form by economists, but not usually by ordinary people
good.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: In the real free market, the users bear the costs of a good or service.
good.translation[4].definitions[1].defin: to have £10, $50 etc more than before or to have made a profit of £10, $50 etc
good.translation[4].definitions[1].examp: Guinness shares closed 6.5p to the good at 608.5p.
